timeline.message: add IntelliJ configuration (version 2020.1)

.idea: keep the run configurations in here

Looks like the only reason to have them elsewhere is if .idea is gitignored.

https://blog.jetbrains.com/idea/2020/03/intellij-idea-2020-1-beta2/#store_run_configurations_as_files
comments on gitignores
.idea: @In annotation indicates an entry point
.idea: all the old run configs

.idea: set the module name in the run configs

this is the IDEA-module-name, not the Teresology-module-name, or the Java-module-name.
.idea: remove my demo run configs now that we converted the others

.idea: extract configs on startup

to get the checkstyle config

.idea: test coverage

show test coverage for engine, not all Java packages in the universe
.idea: extract natives as well as configs on startup
.idea: set copyright profile name to match the old config
chore: remove stray engine-tests outputs
.idea: add copyInMissingTemplates to startup task

gradle: remove the direct xml modifications of idea configs

The goal is to keep the configs checked-in under .idea/, or as settings on the gradle builds or the gradle idea plugin, rather than direct XML hacking.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/develop' into maint/dot-idea

# Conflicts:
#	.gitignore
style(idea): don't even use * with awt
idea: some demonstration scopes
idea: don't put a big copyright statement in .properties files
enhancement(gradle): automatically set "build and run using: IntelliJ IDEA"
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/develop' into maint/dot-idea
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/develop' into maint/dot-idea

replies.bodyText:
It is. I was worried too. But apparently this is the way it's supposed to work. See the section about dictionaries on https://keturn.net/blog/posts/2020/05/git-add-dot-idea-share-intellij/
(oh, I should add id fragments to those sections)
replies.author: keturn

timeline.author: DarkWeird
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
+<project version="4">
+  <component name="EntryPointsManager">
+    <list size="4">
+      <item index="0" class="java.lang.String" itemvalue="org.terasology.entitySystem.event.ReceiveEvent" />
+      <item index="1" class="java.lang.String" itemvalue="org.terasology.entitySystem.systems.RegisterSystem" />
+      <item index="2" class="java.lang.String" itemvalue="org.terasology.logic.console.commandSystem.annotations.Command" />
+      <item index="3" class="java.lang.String" itemvalue="org.terasology.registry.In" />
+    </list>
+    <writeAnnotations>
+      <writeAnnotation name="org.terasology.registry.In" />
+    </writeAnnotations>
+  </component>
+  <component name="ExternalStorageConfigurationManager" enabled="true" />
+  <component name="ProjectRootManager" version="2" languageLevel="JDK_1_8" default="false" project-jdk-name="liberica-11" project-jdk-type="JavaSDK" />

replies.bodyText:
I think this is okay too. It specifies which JDK to use for the project, but it doesn't encode any machine-specific path to exactly where "liberica-11" is installed for you, so it can be whatever JDK you have with that name.
You can download and install the liberica distributions directly from the add JDK menu. Hopefully I left it with the default name it gives when you do that?
but this is definitely a good thing to get feedback on, as it really will be a mess if it doesn't work the way I think it does
replies.author: keturn
